facts.text: The respondent, a scheduled bank, sued the appellant in the court of the Civil Judge, Sitapur in Uttar Pradesh for recovery of money due under a mortgage instrument.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, a scheduled bank, sued the appellant in the companyrt of the Civil Judge, Sitapore in Uttar Pradesh, for the recovery of money due under an instrument of mortgage.

facts.text: The respondent is a scheduled bank.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, a scheduled bank, sued the appellant in the companyrt of the Civil Judge, Sitapore in Uttar Pradesh, for the recovery of money due under an instrum

facts.text: Appellant contested the suit on several grounds including entitlement to relief under Uttar Pradesh Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, U.P. XV of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytested the suit on several grounds one of which was that he was entitled to relief under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindars Debt Reduction Act  U.P. XV of 1953  which reduced the amount recoverable on a debt as defined in it.

facts.text: Uttar Pradesh Zamindars Debt Reduction Act is U.P. XV of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindars Debt Reduction Act  U.P. XV of 1953  which reduced the amount recoverable on a debt as defined in it. Now a debt was defined in the Act in these terms 2 f  debt means an advance in cash or in kind and includes any transaction which is in substance a debt but does number include an advance as aforesaid made on or after the first day of July, 1952 or a debt due to - the Central Government or Government of any State a local authority a scheduled bank a companyorative society and a waqf, trust or endowment for a charitable or religious purpose only.

facts.text: The Act reduces the amount recoverable on a debt as defined in it.

anchor.surface_text: XV of 1953  which reduced the amount recoverable on a debt as defined in it. Now a debt was defined in the Act in these terms 2 f  debt means an advance in cash or in kind and includes any transaction which is in substance a debt but does number include an advance as aforesaid made on or after the first day of July, 1952 or a debt due to - the Central Government or Government of any State a local authority a scheduled bank a companyorative society and a waqf, trust or endowment for a charitable or religious purpose only. a person, where the debt was advanced on his behalf by the Court of Wards to a ward.

facts.text: Debt under the Act excludes advances made on or after July 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: debt means an advance in cash or in kind and includes any transaction which is in substance a debt but does number include an advance as aforesaid made on or after the first day of July, 1952 or a debt due to - the Central Government or Government of any State a local authority a scheduled bank a companyorative society and a waqf, trust or endowment for a charitable or religious purpose only.

facts.text: Debt under the Act excludes debts due to scheduled banks.

anchor.surface_text: a scheduled bank a companyorative society and a waqf, trust or endowment for a charitable or religious purpose only. a person, where the debt was advanced on his behalf by the Court of Wards to a ward. As the respondent was a scheduled bank the debt due to it from the appellant was number a debt within this definition and companysequently, numberrelief would appear to be available to the appellant under the Act in respect of that debt.

facts.text: Debt due from appellant to respondent is not a debt under the Act because respondent is scheduled bank.

anchor.surface_text: As the respondent was a scheduled bank the debt due to it from the appellant was number a debt within this definition and companysequently, numberrelief would appear to be available to the appellant under the Act in respect of that debt. The appellant, however, companytended that the definition in so far as it excluded certain debts offended Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and denied the excluded debtors, the equal protection of the law and that hence that portion of the definition which excluded certain debts was invalid and should be struck out and the rest of the definition should be left as operative.

facts.text: Appellant contended that the exclusion of certain debts in the definition offends Article 14 of the Constitution as it makes arbitrary distinction between classes of debtors.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, companytended that the definition in so far as it excluded certain debts offended Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and denied the excluded debtors, the equal protection of the law and that hence that portion of the definition which excluded certain debts was invalid and should be struck out and the rest of the definition should be left as operative. If the appellants companytention was justified, the definition would have to run as follows debt means an advance in cash or in companyn and includes any transaction which is in substance a debt, and would then include the debt due by the appellant to the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant applied to Civil Judge, Sitapur under proviso to section 113 CPC to state case to High Court Allahabad on invalidity of impugned definition portion.

anchor.surface_text: So the appellant made an application to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, under the proviso to s. 113 of the Code of Civil Procedure asking him to state a case for the opinion of the High Court at Allahabad to which he was subordinate as to the invalidity of the impugned portion of the definition.

facts.text: Civil Judge held impugned portion of definition infringed Article 14 and was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge took the view that the impugned portion of the definition infringed art. 14 of the Constitution as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and was therefore invalid, but he held that it was number necessary for the disposal of the case to decide such question of invalidity because even if it was decided in favour of the appellant, the result would be to exclude the entire definition from the Act as the offending portion was number severable from the rest and the appellant would, therefore, be in any event left without the protection of the Act.

facts.text: Civil Judge held that deciding invalidity not necessary as offending portion not severable, entire definition excluded, no relief to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: but he held that it was number necessary for the disposal of the case to decide such question of invalidity because even if it was decided in favour of the appellant, the result would be to exclude the entire definition from the Act as the offending portion was number severable from the rest and the appellant would, therefore, be in any event left without the protection of the Act. In this view of the matter he held that the proviso to s. 113 of the Code did number apply and dismissed the application under it.

facts.text: Civil Judge dismissed the application under proviso to s.113 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter he held that the proviso to s. 113 of the Code did number apply and dismissed the application under it. The appellant then made an application to the High Court at Allahabad for a revision of the order of the learned Civil Judge.

facts.text: Appellant filed revision application in High Court Allahabad against Civil Judge's order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then made an application to the High Court at Allahabad for a revision of the order of the learned Civil Judge. He at the same time made another application to the High Court under Art. 228 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellant filed application under Article 228 Constitution in High Court to withdraw the case.

anchor.surface_text: He at the same time made another application to the High Court under Art. 228 of the Constitution. That article is in these terms If the High Court is satisfied that a case pending in a companyrt subordinate to it involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of this Constitution the determination of which is necessary for the disposal of the case, it shall withdraw the case and may -  a  either dispose of the case itself, or  b  determine the said question of law and return the case to the companyrt from which the case has been so withdrawn together with a companyy of its judgment on such question, and the said companyrt shall on receipt thereof proceed to dispose of the case in companyformity with such judgment.

facts.text: High Court dismissed both applications by one judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disposed of both the applications by one judgment. It held that there was numberdispute as to the companystitutional principle which was clear, namely, that every citizen was entitled to the equal protection of the laws and that any enactment which infringed that principle, is to that extent void, and that the only dispute was whether the impugned portion of the definition of a debt in the Act was severable from the rest and that was number a question of the interpretation of any provision of the Constitution but one of the companystruction of the Act itself.

facts.text: High Court held that the dispute on severability is construction of Act, not interpretation of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It held that there was numberdispute as to the companystitutional principle which was clear, namely, that every citizen was entitled to the equal protection of the laws and that any enactment which infringed that principle, is to that extent void, and that the only dispute was whether the impugned portion of the definition of a debt in the Act was severable from the rest and that was number a question of the interpretation of any provision of the Constitution but one of the companystruction of the Act itself. The High Court also held that even if any question of the interpretation of the Constitution arose, a determination of that question was number necessary for the disposal of case.

facts.text: Appeal filed to Supreme Court from High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter the High Court dismissed the application in revision and also that under Art. 228. From this judgment the present appeal has been filed.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the question of validity of the provision is necessary for disposal of the case.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case. This appeal is hence allowed. The High Court will withdraw the case and either dispose it of itself or determine the question of the validity of the definition of a debt in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act and return the case to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, for disposal in accordance with its determination of the question.

facts.text: Supreme Court allows the appeal and directs High Court to withdraw the case or determine the question and return it.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is hence allowed. The High Court will withdraw the case and either dispose it of itself or determine the question of the validity of the definition of a debt in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act and return the case to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, for disposal in accordance with its determination of the question.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejects lower courts' view that severability makes decision on validity unnecessary.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrts below held that in either view of the question of the validity of the impugned portion of the definition of a debt, the appellant would be without the remedy which he sought, because that portion of the definition was number severable from the rest, and therefore it was number necessary to decide that question of dispose of the case. We are unable to agree with this view.

issues.text: Whether the definition of 'debt' in Section 2(f) of the Uttar Pradesh Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, insofar as it excludes certain debts due to scheduled banks etc., offends Article 14 of the Constitution by making an arbitrary distinction between classes of debtors?

anchor.surface_text: offended Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and denied the excluded debtors, the equal protection of the law and that hence that portion of the definition which excluded certain debts was invalid and should be struck out and the rest of the definition should be left as operative.

issues.text: Whether the determination of the validity of the impugned portion of the definition of 'debt' is necessary for the disposal of the case?

anchor.surface_text: The point that really arises in this appeal is whether it is necessary for the disposal of the case to decide the question of the validity of a portion of the definition of a debt in the Act. All other conditions necessary for an order being made under the proviso to s. 113 of the Code or Art. 228 of the Constitution exist

issues.text: Whether the impugned portion of the definition of 'debt' excluding certain debts is severable from the rest of the definition?

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge took the view that the impugned portion of the definition infringed art. 14 of the Constitution as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and was therefore invalid, but he held that it was not necessary for the disposal of the case to decide such question of invalidity because even if it was decided in favour of the appellant, the result would be to exclude the entire definition from the Act as the offending portion was not severable from the rest

issues.text: Whether the question raised falls within the proviso to Section 113 of the Code of Civil Procedure?

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution. The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it while Art. 228 of the Constitution has in view a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution.

issues.text: Whether the question raised involves a substantial question of law as to the interpretation of the Constitution under Article 228?

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution. The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it while Art. 228 of the Constitution has in view a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution. Now the question raised in the present case is as to the validity of a provision in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act.

arguments.claim: The exclusion of certain debts (due to scheduled banks etc.) in the definition of 'debt' under Section 2(f) of the U.P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act offends Article 14 of the Constitution by making an arbitrary distinction between classes of debtors, denying equal protection, and thus that portion is invalid and should be struck out, leaving the rest operative.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, however, contended that the definition in so far as it excluded certain debts offended Art. 14 of the Constitution in as much as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and denied the excluded debtors, the equal protection of the law and that hence that portion of the definition which excluded certain debts was invalid and should be struck out and the rest of the definition should be left as operative. If the appellants contention was justified, the definition would have to run as follows debt means an advance in cash or in kind and includes any transaction which is in substance a debt, and would then include the debt due by the appellant to the respondent.

arguments.claim: The impugned portion of the definition of 'debt' infringes Article 14 by making an arbitrary distinction between classes of debtors and is invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Civil Judge took the view that the impugned portion of the definition infringed art. 14 of the Constitution as it made an arbitrary distinction between several classes of debtors and was therefore invalid, but he held that it was not necessary for the disposal of the case to decide such question of invalidity because even if it was decided in favour of the appellant, the result would be to exclude the entire definition from the Act as the offending portion was not severable from the rest and the appellant would, therefore, be in any event left without the protection of the Act.

In this view of the matter he held that the proviso to s. 113 of the Code did not apply and dismissed the application under it.

arguments.claim: The question raised comes within the proviso to s.113 CPC and Art.228 because it concerns validity of a provision, which is also interpretation of the Constitution as it contravenes an article.

anchor.surface_text: From this judgment the present appeal has been filed. It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution. The question contemplated by the proviso to s. 113 of the Code is as to the validity of an Act or of a provision in it while Art. 228 of the Constitution has in view a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution. Now the question raised in the present case is as to the validity of a provision in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act. This question is, however also a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution, for the validity of the provision is challenged on the ground that it contravenes an article of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: , a determination of that question was number necessary for the disposal of case. In this view of the matter the High Court dismissed the application

arguments.claim: It is necessary for disposal of the case to decide the validity of the impugned portion of the definition; lower courts erred in holding otherwise based on non-severability.

anchor.surface_text: The point that really arises in this appeal is whether it is necessary for the disposal of the case to decide the question of the validity of a portion of the definition of a debt in the Act. All other conditions necessary for an order being made under the proviso to s. 113 of the Code or Art. 228 of the Constitution exist and as to this there is no serious dispute. It is not necessary for us therefore to discuss these conditions. The courts below held that in either view of the question of the validity of the impugned portion of the definition of a debt, the appellant would be without the remedy which he sought, because that portion of the definition was not severable from the rest, and therefore it was not necessary to decide that question to dispose of the case. We are unable to agree with this view.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the Constitution. The point that really arises in this appeal is whether it is necessary for the disposal of the case to decide the question of th

arguments.claim: Severability of the impugned part arises only after it is held invalid; cannot use non-severability to avoid deciding validity, as the question was raised and pressed.

anchor.surface_text: The question of the validity of the definition in so far as it excluded certain debts having been raised and pressed by the appellant, it had to be decided by the court. Without a decision of that question the case could not be disposed of. The fact that in the view of the court the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest and therefore in any view of the question as to the validity of the impugned part, the appellant would not get any relief, did not alter the position. The question as to the severability of the impugned part of the definition from the rest would arise only after it had been decided that the impugned part was invalid and so to be able to say that the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest, it had first to be held that that part was invalid.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: gned portion of the definition of a debt, the appellant would be without the remedy which he sought, because that portion of the definition was number

holdings.text: The question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.113 proviso covers validity of statutory provision; Art.228 covers constitutional interpretation; instant question matches both as validity challenged on constitutional contravention.

holdings.text: The question as to the validity of a provision in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act is also a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution, for the validity of the provision is challenged on the ground that it contravenes an article of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Now the question raised in the present case is as to the validity of a provision in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act. This question is, however also a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution, for the validity of the provision is challenged on the ground that it contravenes an article of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity challenge grounded in contravention of constitutional article necessarily involves interpreting the Constitution to assess compliance.

holdings.text: It is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that it is necessary to decide the question of the validity of the impugned part of the definition to dispose of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Question raised and pressed by appellant; lower courts erred by assuming non-severability to bypass decision on validity, which must precede severability analysis.

holdings.text: The question as to the severability of the impugned part of the definition from the rest would arise only after it had been decided that the impugned part was invalid and so to be able to say that the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest, it had first to be held that that part was invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The question of the validity of the definition in so far as it excluded certain debts having been raised and pressed by the appellant, it had to be decided by the court. Without a decision of that question the case could not be disposed of. The fact that in the view of the court the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest and therefore in any view of the question as to the validity of the impugned part, the appellant would not get any relief, did not alter the position. The question as to the severability of the impugned part of the definition from the rest would arise only after it had been decided that the impugned part was invalid and so to be able to say that the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest, it had first to be held that that part was invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Logical priority: invalidity must be determined before assessing severability; cannot invoke non-severability to evade deciding validity when raised.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is hence allowed. The High Court will withdraw the case and either dispose it of itself or determine the question of the validity of the definition of a debt in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act and return the case to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, for disposal in accordance with its determination of the question.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court directed to withdraw the case from Civil Judge, Sitapur under Art. 228 and either dispose of it itself or determine the validity question and return to the Civil Judge for disposal accordingly.
directions: The High Court will withdraw the case and either dispose it of itself or determine the question of the validity of the definition of a debt in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act and return the case to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, for disposal in accordance with its determination of the question.

anchor.surface_text: It seems clear to us that the question raised by the appellant in this case comes within the proviso to s. 113 of the Code as also art. 228 of the Constitution.

This appeal is hence allowed. The High Court will withdraw the case and either dispose it of itself or determine the question of the validity of the definition of a debt in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act and return the case to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, for disposal in accordance with its determination of the question.

Now the question raised in the present case is as to the validity of a provision in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act. This question is, however also a question as to the interpretation of the Constitution, for the validity of the provision is challenged on the ground that it contravenes an article of the Constitution.

This appeal is hence allowed. The High Court will withdraw the case and either dispose it of itself or determine the question of the validity of the definition of a debt in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act and return the case to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, for disposal in accordance with its determination of the question.

edges.explanation: Holding states that severability question arises only after invalidity decided, addressing i3.

anchor.surface_text: The question of the validity of the definition in so far as it excluded certain debts having been raised and pressed by the appellant, it had to be decided by the court. Without a decision of that question the case could not be disposed of. The fact that in the view of the court the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest and therefore in any view of the question as to the validity of the impugned part, the appellant would not get any relief, did not alter the position. The question as to the severability of the impugned part of the definition from the rest would arise only after it had been decided that the impugned part was invalid and so to be able to say that the impugned part of the definition was not severable from the rest, it had first to be held that that part was invalid.

This appeal is hence allowed. The High Court will withdraw the case and either dispose it of itself or determine the question of the validity of the definition of a debt in the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act and return the case to the Civil Judge, Sitapur, for disposal in accordance with its determination of the question.
